📋 Instructions

You will rotate through 4 stations exploring different Indigenous governance systems. At each station, record key information about how these communities organize themselves and make decisions.

Remember: We are learning about these systems with respect and curiosity, not claiming to practice them ourselves.

Station 1: Te Ao Māori Governance

Key governance structure you learned about:

How are decisions made in this system?

What values guide this governance approach?

One thing that surprised or impressed you:

Station 2: Pacific Governance Systems

Key governance structure you learned about:

How are decisions made in this system?

What values guide this governance approach?

One thing that surprised or impressed you:

Station 3: First Nations Governance

Key governance structure you learned about:

How are decisions made in this system?

What values guide this governance approach?

One thing that surprised or impressed you:

Station 4: Other Indigenous Models

Key governance structure you learned about:

How are decisions made in this system?

What values guide this governance approach?

One thing that surprised or impressed you:

🔍 Common Principles Analysis

What common values or principles did you notice across these different Indigenous governance systems?

How do these approaches differ from governance systems you're more familiar with?

Which principles or approaches do you think could be valuable for any society? Why?

🏗️ Application to Your Society Design

Choose 2-3 principles from Indigenous governance that could strengthen your group's society design:

Principle 1:

How will you apply this in your society?

Principle 2:

How will you apply this in your society?

Principle 3 (optional):

How will you apply this in your society?

💭 Personal Reflection

What's one new perspective you gained about leadership and governance from today's learning?

How might this learning influence how you participate in your school, whānau, or community?

🌿 Cultural Safety Reminder

Important: Indigenous knowledge systems are living traditions that belong to specific communities. We learn about them to:

  • Understand different ways of organizing society
  • Appreciate the wisdom in diverse approaches to governance
  • Consider how these insights might inform our own society design
  • Develop respect for Indigenous ways of knowing

We do not claim to practice or represent these traditions ourselves.
